metadata.priority: string - high|medium|low based on content importance

inferabilityGuidelines: Use [INFERABLE - NOT STORED] for pure acknowledgments with no new information
Use [INFERABLE] inline for obvious connecting phrases or redundant parts
Never mark factual information, insights, or substantive responses as inferable
Common inferable responses: 'You're welcome', 'Happy to help', 'Sure!', 'Of course'
When uncertain, err on the side of preserving content
alwaysPreserve: Life decisions and personal choices (career, relationships, health, major life direction)
Important conclusions and determinations (any resolution or decision made)
Action items and commitments (what will be done or changed)
Insights and realizations (breakthrough moments or understanding)
priorityHierarchy: Life content and personal decisions (highest priority)

expectedOutput.fullResponse: A red dwarf is a small, relatively cool star that makes up the vast majority of stars in our galaxy. They burn their fuel slowly and can live for trillions of years, making them the longest-lived stars in the universe.
expectedOutput.trim: Boss: What is a red dwarf?\nSamara: red dwarf: small cool star, 70% of galaxy stars, burns slowly, lives trillions years, longest-lived.

expectedOutput.fullResponse: You're welcome! I'm happy to help with any other astronomy questions you might have.

input.bossMessage: Can you also tell me about their planets?

expectedOutput.fullResponse: Yes! Red dwarf planets are fascinating. Many red dwarfs have been found to host rocky planets, often in very close orbits. The habitable zone around a red dwarf is much closer to the star due to its lower temperature. However, planets in this zone face challenges like tidal locking and stellar flares.
expectedOutput.trim: Boss: Can you also tell me about their planets?\nSamara: [INFERABLE acknowledgment] red dwarf planets: rocky, close orbits, habitable zone closer. Challenges: tidal locking, stellar flares.

input.bossMessage: I'm thinking of switching careers to data science. What do you think?

I'd recommend taking an online course first to see if you genuinely enjoy the work before making the full transition.
